Rules: X no atari no

Explanation: Y in the vicinity of X
Rules: Y no atari de X @ X = action, Y = noun
hoka ni X Y @ X = characteristic, Y = place
X no hoka ni Y
nan + (counter) + ka.

Explanation: Sentences where nanika is used instead of nanidemo.

Rules: dono + (noun) + demo.
donna + (noun) + demo.

Explanation: Use "dou" in normal form, "kou" in reply to "dou".

Rules: X kamo shirenai @ X = verb plain form (incl. plain neg. or past)
X kamo shirenai da @ X = i-adj.
X kamo shirenai da @ X = na-adj.
X kamo shirenai da @ X = noun

Explanation: Used at the end of a sentence to provide emphasis when giving information. Use "yo" for male and "da yo"/"wa yo"  for female colloquial speech.
Rules: X yo / X n da yo / X wa yo @ X = verb
X yo / X da yo / X wa yo @ X = noun/na-adj./i-adj.
X ka @ X = verb
Raise tone and omit "ka" when question is in plain form.
kai or "kae" also used in familiar language.

Explanation: Used similarly to the interrogative "ka" after a verb, "ka naa" is used by males and "ka shira" by females.
Rules: X ka naa/ka shira

Explanation: no is sometimes used to stress the uncertaintyl/doubt.
Rules: X no ka naa/ka shira @ X = verb, i-adj.
X na no ka naa/ka shira @ X = noun, na-adj.
X ga Y @ X = object, Y = normal verb in tai form
X ga Y @ X = object, Y = normal verb in eru form (all tenses)
X ga Y @ X = object, Y = normal verb in passive form
X ga Y @ X = object, Y = normal verb in other special tenses
X ga Y @ X = object, Y = ii, warui, suki, kirai
X ga @ X = unknown subject
X ga @ X = response to question about subject
X ga @ X = new information
X ga @ X = emphasized subject
X ga Y @ X = subject, Y = special verb in affirmative form (e.g. aru, furu)
Use "X ni … wo …" construction when the verb originally uses the "wo" marker, e.g. "wo taberu".
Use "X wo … ni …" construction when the verb requires the use of the "ni" marker, e.g. "ni iku".

Explanation: X just the way it is. Used to emphasize a fact or action.
Rules: X mama @ X = verb ta/nai/passive form
X no mama @ X = noun
X mama @ X = i-adj., na-adj., demonstrative adj. (kono, sono, ano)

Explanation: X the way it is meant to be, X as planned, just as X. Used to emphasize a fact or action. Use "doori" when juxtaposing "toori" to a noun to create a compund noun.
Rules: X toori (ni) @ X = verb plain form
X (no) toori/doori (ni) @ X = noun

Explanation: It would be best if X. Used to emphasize an action or state of being.
Rules: X hou ga ii da @ X = verb ta form for affirmative phrase
X hou ga ii da @ X = verb nai form for negative phrase
X mitai da @ X = verb plain form
X mitai da @ X = noun

Explanation: (He) seems to [do/be] X / (I've) heard that X (from what I can see). Note that there are two verb constructions involving "sou", with different meanings.
Rules: X sou @ X = verb root (for plain present), verb plain form (for other tenses)
X sou ni / sou mo nai @ X = verb masu stem
X sou @ X = i-adj. root (exceptions: ii >> yosasou)
X da sou @ X = na-adj.
X da sou @ X = noun: this form is not used, X mitai is used instead

Explanation: Similar usage to "to" as casual quoting particle. Using "n" softens the phrase.
Rules: X tte @ X = verb plain form, i-adj.
X n datte @ X = verb plain form, i-adj.
X datte @ X = noun, na-adj.
X na n datte @ X = noun, na-adj.

Explanation: (He) seems to [do/be] X (from what I can deduce).
Rules: X you da @ X = verb plain form, i-adj.
X na you da @ X = na-adj.
X no you da @ X = noun
X mo @ X = verb te form
X kutemo @ X = i-adj. root
X de mo @ X = na-adj., noun
X sugiru @ X = verb "i" stem
X sugiru @ X = i-adj. root
X sugiru @ X = na-adj.
X baai wa @ X = verb plain form, i-adj.
X na baai wa @ X = na-adj.
X no baai @ X = noun

Explanation: If X then Y. Reference to fact that exists, not necessarily an obvious one.
Rules: X da to Y @ X = noun/na-adj., Y = phrase
X to Y @ X = verb/i-adj., Y = phrase
X nara/naraba Y @ X = noun (use "naraba" in formal sentences)
X nara/naraba Y @ X = na-adj. (use "naraba" in formal sentences)
X ba Y @ X ba = verb in ba form. If X is an action verb, Y cannot describe a speaker's will, hope, order, judgment, request, invitation, permission, prohibition, etc..
X kereba Y @ X = affirmative i-adj. or root of verb with "eiru" or "tai" ending
X de nakereba Y @ X = noun
X de nakereba Y @ X = na-adj.
X Y @ X = verb in nakereba form. If X is an action verb, Y cannot describe a speaker's will, hope, order, judgment, request, invitation, permission, prohibition, etc..
X kunakereba Y @ X = i-adj. or verb in tai form

Explanation: If not X then Y. Colloquial form of "nakereba".
Rules: X de nakya Y @ X = noun
X de nakya Y @ X = na-adj.
X Y @ X = verb in nakya form. If X is an action verb, Y cannot describe a speaker's will, hope, order, judgment, request, invitation, permission, prohibition, etc..
X kunakya Y @ X = i-adj. or verb in tai form

Explanation: Because of X. "shi" is usually used to provide a list of reasons, and is repeated as necessary.
Rules: X shi Y @ X = affirmative i-adj. or root of verb with "eiru" or "tai" ending
X da shi Y @ X = noun
X da shi Y @ X = na-adj.
X shi @ X = verb
X dattara Y @ X = noun, Y = sentence in present tense
X dattara Y @ X = na-adj., Y = sentence in present tense
X tara/dara Y @ X tara/dara = verb in tara form, Y = sentence in present tense
X kattara Y @ X = i-adj. or verb in ta form, Y = sentence in present tense
X dattara Y @ X = noun/na-adj., Y = sentence in past tense
X tara/dara Y @ X tara/dara = verb in tara form, Y = sentence in past tense
X kattara Y @ X = i-adj. or verb in ta form, Y = sentence in past tense
X de nakattara Y @ X = noun/na-adj., Y = sentence in present tense
X nakattara Y @ X nakattara = verb in nakattara form, Y = sentence in present tense
X ku nakattara Y @ X = i-adj. or verb in ta form, Y = sentence in present tense
X de nakattara Y @ X = noun/na-adj., Y = sentence in past tense
X nakattara Y @ X nakattara = verb in nakattara form, Y = sentence in past tense
X ku nakattara Y @ X = i-adj. or verb in ta form, Y = sentence in past tense
X dakara Y @ X = noun, na-adj., conjugated i-adj., implied fact
X kara Y @ X = verb plain form, i-adj. plain form

Explanation: X therefore Y. Softer and more polite than "kara", used to distance cause from consequence.
Rules: X nanode Y @ X = noun, na-adj., implied fact
X node Y @ X = verb plain/masu form, i-adj.

Explanation: X therefore Y. Colloquial form of "node", used to distance cause from consequence.
Rules: X nande Y @ X = noun, na-adj., implied fact
X nde Y @ X = verb plain form, i-adj.

Explanation: X therefore Y. Usually with the connotation "is so X that Y". The "te/de" ending is also used when the phrase X is originally set in the past.
Rules: X Y @ X = verb te form
X Y @ X = i-adj. te form
X Y @ X = na-adj.
X Y @ X = noun
X. demo Y @ X/Y = phrase
X temo/demo Y @ X/Y = phrase

Explanation: Often used after politer sentence or after a masu verb.
Rules: X desu/deshita ga Y @ X = noun, na-adj.
X ga Y @ X = verb masu form (present or past), i-adj.
X desu/deshita ga Y @ X = noun, na-adj.
X ga Y @ X = verb masu form (present or past)
X i/katta ga Y @ X = i-adj.
X da kedo Y @ X = noun, na-adj., implied fact
X kedo Y @ X = verb plain form, i-adj.

Explanation: X and Y. Less common usage.
Rules: X da kedo Y @ X = noun, na-adj.
X kedo Y @ X = verb, i-adj.

Explanation: X but Y. Politer form of kedo.
Rules: X da keredomo Y @ X = noun, na-adj.
X keredomo Y @ X = verb, i-adj.

Explanation: Y despite X. Y even though X. The sentence is sometimes ended in "noni" to ascribe disappointment or surprise over a certain event.
Rules: X nanoni Y @ X = noun, na-adj. (present)
X datta noni Y @ X = na-adj. (past)
X noni Y @ X = verb plain form, i-adj.

Explanation: X and Y (amongst other things). Used when describing states of being.
Rules: X da shi Y shi/da shi @ X = noun, na-adj.
X shi Y shi/da shi @ X = verb,  i-adj.

Explanation: X and/or Y. "tari" is usually used to provide a list of alternate possibilities, and is repeated as necessary. Usage is [X tari] ... [Y tari] suru, where "suru" is conjugated and controls the overall tense.
Rules: X/Y suru @ X/Y = verb in tari form
X/Y dattari suru @ X/Y = na-adj/noun
X/Y suru @ X/Y = i-adj in kattari form

Explanation: Y happening at the same time as X.
Rules: X no toki Y @ X = noun, Y in present tense
X na toki Y @ X = na-adj., Y in present tense
X toki Y @ X = verb dict. form/i-adj., Y in present tense

Explanation: Y happened/will have happened/is agreed upon to happen at the same time as X.
Rules: X datta toki Y @ X = noun/na-adj., Y in past tense
X toki Y @ X = verb ta form, Y in past tense
X katta toki Y @ X = i-adj., Y in past tense

Explanation: Y happening while X is still happening.
Rules: X no uchi ni Y @ X = noun
X na uchi ni Y @ X = na-adj.
X uchi ni Y @ X = verb, i-adj.

Explanation: Y for the benefit of X, for the sake of something certain.
Rules: X no tame no Y @ X = noun, Y = noun
X no tame ni Y @ X = noun, Y = verb
X da to iu @ X = noun, na-adj.
X to iu @ X = verb plain form, i-adj.
X da to omou @ X = noun, na-adj.
X to omou @ X = verb plain form, i-adj.
X da to wa kagiranai @ X = noun, na-adj.
X to wa kagiranai @ X = verb plain form, i-adj.

Explanation: I don't Y if X is ... or not
Rules: X ka dou ka Y @ X = plain verb, Y = know/think/believe/etc..
X ka dou ka Y @ X = i-adj, Y = know/think/believe/etc..
X ka dou ka Y @ X = na-adj/noun, Y = know/think/believe/etc..
X hazu da @ X = verb dict. form, i-adj.
X na hazu da @ X = na-adj.
X no hazu da @ X = noun
X hazu ga/wa nai @ X = verb nai form (double negative sentence)
X hazu da @ X = i-adj. negative (double negative sentence)
X na hazu da @ X = na-adj. negative (double negative sentence)
X hazu da @ X = adnominal adjective (e.g. konna)
X hazu da @ X = verb nai form (expresses certainty)
X kunai hazu da @ X kunai = i-adj. negative (expresses certainty)
X ja/dewa nai hazu da @ X = na-adj. negative (expresses certainty)
X hazu ga/wa nai @ X = verb dict. form (expresses denial)
X hazu ga/wa nai @ X = i-adj. affirmative (expresses denial)
X na hazu ga/wa nai @ X = na-adj. affirmative (expresses denial)
X hazu ga/wa nai @ X = adnominal adjective (e.g. konna)
X hazu da @ X = verb ta form/i-adj. past affirmative
X datta hazu da @ X = noun/na-adj.
X hazu datta @ X = adnominal adjective (e.g. konna)
X hazu datta @ X = verb dict. form/i-adj. present affirmative
X na hazu datta @ X = na-adj. present affirmative
X no hazu datta @ X = noun

Explanation: Was certainly not supposed to [do/be] X.
Rules: X hazu ja/dewa nakatta @ X = verb ta form/i-adj. present affirmative/adnominal adj. (e.g. konna)
X na hazu ja/dewa nakatta @ X = na-adj. present affirmative
X no hazu ja/dewa nakatta @ X = noun

Explanation: Concerning X, about X, relating to X, regarding X.
Rules: X ni tsuite no Y @ Y = noun
X ni tsuite Y @ Y = verb

Explanation: Becoming X. Used as a general statement. For a statement from a personal point of view, the past tense is used (natta/narimashita).
Rules: X ni naru @ X = na-adj.
X ni naru @ X = noun
X ku naru @ X = i-adj.
X you ni naru @ X = verb plain form

Explanation: Became X. Used as a statement from a personal point of view. For a general reference, the present tense is used (naru/narimasu).
Rules: X ni natta @ X = noun, na-adj.
X ku natta @ X = i-adj.
X you ni natta @ X = verb
X yori Y hou ga @ X = verb dict. form/i-adj. present, Y = verb ta form/i-adj. present
X yori Y no hou ga @ X/Y = noun
X na yori Y na hou ga @ X/Y = na-adj. present
Y X yori @ X = verb dict. form/noun/i-adj. present, Y = verb ta form/noun/i-adj. present
Y X na yori @ X/Y = na-adj. present
X noto Y noto/nanoto @ X = noun, verb, i-adj.
X nanoto Y noto/nanoto @ X = na-adj.

Explanation: X seems to be like Y, X looks like Y.
Rules: X you na Y @ X = action, Y = noun
X you ni Y @ X = action, Y = verb
X no you ni Y @ X = noun, Y = noun
X no you na Y @ X = noun, Y = verb
X sou na Y @ X = i-adj., Y = noun
X sou na Y @ X = na-adj., Y = noun
X no ato (de) @ X = noun
X ato @ X = noun (higher form)
X ato de @ X = action verb plain past
X no mae ni @ X = noun
X mae ni @ X = action verb plain present
X te Y @ X/Y = action verb
X Y (without "te") @ X/Y = action verb, used only in written form
Use "kochira koso" in reply.

Explanation: Thanks in advance / I'm counting on you / I'm in your debt. (used with respect to co-workers)
Please be kind to me / treat me well.

Rules: When apologizing.
More formal expression.
Less formal expression.

Explanation: Refers to something that affects the speaker. The "n" acts as a softener for humility, since the speaker is refering to him/herself.
Rules: X da to ii n desu ga @ X = noun/na-adj.
X to ii n desu ga @ X = verb/i-adj.

Explanation: Refers to something that affects someone who is not the speaker.
Rules: X da to ii desu ne @ X = noun/na-adj.
X to ii desu ne @ X = verb/i-adj.
X tame @ X = verb plain past
X no tame @ X = phrase plain present

Explanation: X and Y and so forth. Used to list multiple examples, usually to express dissatisfaction or a negative action/fact.
Rules: X dano Y (datta) dano @ X = i-adj., verb
X dano Y (datta) dano @ X = noun/na-adj. in present tense
X datta dano Y (datta) dano @ X = noun/na-adj. in past tense

Explanation: Used when contemplating two or more opposing choices (ie. choices have opposite meanings). "no" is added to express uncertainty. Often used in conversations.
Rules: X yara Y yara @ X = noun/i-adj.
X no yara Y (na) no yara @ X = verb/i-adj.
X na no yara Y (na) no yara @ X = na-adj.
X da to tsutaeru @ X = noun/na-adj.
X to tsutaeru @ X = verb plain form/i-adj.
